comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content: Best I could find in Trove is that the tug was mentioned in the newspapers from 1947 to 1957 and is referred to as a diesel tug. It was used as a fire fighting tog in the lat 1950's based at Goat Island.

comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content:
I later found an article by Graeme Andrews in AFLOAT  June 2002 pp22

He says 

" With the three old fire floats (Hydra, Pluvius and Cecil Rhodes) now structurally inadequate, the MSB took over three new seagoing tugs which had been built to a modified
English steam tug design. Boray, Boambilly and Burrowaree were completed in 1947 by Walkers Ltd in Maryborough, Queensland.

"They were part of a group, units of which were used by the Army, the RAN and by various state government departments. They were the first modern sea-going diesel tugs owned by Australia. Only one of the design was ever fitted with a steam engine, the PWD’s Ben Shortridge, the rest being fitted with National diesels. The Boray type were 99ft overall and had a displacement tonnage of more than 280 tons. They could make 10 knots and were fitted with very powerful water-pumps for their roles as dual purpose fire and towage tugs" .

So the image must  post date 1947
